headline: Beer Brats
description: Beer brats are simmered with onions and spices in beer for extra flavor, then finished up on the grill for a crispy, charred exterior. Serve in buns with mustard.

video.description: Two great things in one delicious meal!
video.name: Beer Brats

name: Beer Brats

recipeInstructions.text: Combine beer and onion slices in a large pot; bring to a boil.
Add bratwurst, pepper flakes, garlic powder, salt, and pepper to beer and onion mixture. Reduce heat to medium and cook for 10 to 12 minutes.
Meanwhile, preheat an outdoor grill for medium-high heat and lightly oil the grate.
Remove bratwurst to a plate. Reduce heat to low and let onions simmer until needed.

Cook bratwurst on the preheated grill, turning occasionally to get char marks, until no longer pink in the middle, 5 to 10 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 160 degrees F (70 degrees C).

review.reviewBody: I love Beer Brats. One of the things we do though is reverse the order. We grill the Brats first, then boil them in beer. This causes them to be juicier and more full. Everything else was great.

Juicy and well cooked! Made some tweaks instead though. We marinated them overnight in Pilsners instead of parboiling them and then grilled them outside for 20-25 min at 350 degrees on the grill. Goes great with Jaeger Spaetzle, sauerkraut, and dijon!

These turned out juicy and flavorful. I will make this again however, next time will use a stronger flavored beer and cut the amount of the red pepper flakes by half. We like hot but my red chilies were a bit much. I did poke holes in the brats with a fork when adding to the beer as suggested by one contributor. I did mix sauerkraut with the onions and warmed before serving.

These are great for tailgating or Sunday football games! Super easy, very flavorful and the cooked down, red-pepper onions were a hit! Didn’t change a thing and these were devoured! Thank you Zach for a new gridiron season favorite!!
I used 3 cans of Guinness. We don’t have a grill so I airfried them. They we delicious. Served them with the onions, brown mustard and sauerkraut!
These were a big hit for us. Boiling in red pepper flakes definitely increased juiciness and flavor after grilling.

I enjoyed this, however, I do not like onions, so I omitted the onions, added a can of sauerkraut (with the juices), then filled the can with water and added with 2 beers. I followed the recipe other than that change and it was good. Thanks for posting.

I only cook 5 brats, there is only 2 of us and that is the “normal “ package size, the only change I do is 1 teaspoon of crushed red pepper instead of 2, but a heaping teaspoon of black pepper, everything else stays the same.
If you do 10 brats double recipe and maybe 3 onions

Never ever boil brats before or after grilling it takes the flavor right out of them. Grill them slowly over medium heat using indirect heat. If you want to keep them warm steam them after grilling with the beer and onions to keep them juicy.
Easy to make and really good tasting
This was a simple recipe and it turned out great! We loved it!
This was a simple recipe and it turned out great! We loved it!

Phenomenal recipe!

I like to add dill and seasoned salt, and serve it on a toasted potato roll with a dill pickle slice. Don't underestimate the red pepper, either. It really takes the recipe over the edge.
I made this exactly as the recipe is written. I grilled this over lump charcoal... very hot. I like the heat from the red pepper flakes... not overwhelming. Everything was just right.
perfect!

I was looking forward to eating these brats because this recipe sounded delish. However, I was disappointed. Boiling them in beer changed the texture and didn’t add any real flavor. If anything, IMO, boiling cause the brats to lose flavor. They weren’t “bad”, they just weren’t all that great.
I have made theses several times and they turn out great. I live in high altitude and my meats always get dry but this is much better than straight up grilling. Thank you!!

I have made brats a bunch of times and decided to change it up and perhaps get more beer flavor by following this. These were dry and terrible. These suckers should be so juicy that they snap when you hit it and the fat drips down you chin. Don’t mess with boiling them, it just over cooks them. I would suggest just putting them straight onto the grill. Try on a lower heat first then sear them off on high heat. Yes it’s a pain because sometimes they don’t cool all the way but trust me it’s worth it to have to cut one open to check.

I’ve been using this recipe for over a year now. Love! I make great use of the beer by reducing it to an au jus. If you plan to reduce, always pick a lighter beer. Dark beers are great for flavoring the brat, but will usually NOT make an edible au jus. Bun not required It’s completely devoured here, so I always have to double the recipe.

LOVED this recipe. It gives the casing that right snap, has a tiny bit of heat, very easy to do. I added a tablespoon of Worcestershire to add to the savory, and ended up pan frying because we don’t have a grill. 10/10 will make again

The spices in this recipe are spot on. I changed it a bit. I browned the brats in butter and sautéed onions with them. I added semi cooked carrots and Brussels sprouts with sauerkraut during the simmer stage. Since the brats were already browned, I didn’t need to go out in the cold to grill them. It was delicious! Even my daughter ate the sauerkraut! This is definitely a recipe I’ll use again!
This is very good. 10/10 will be making again.
Delish. No Changes but I use the beer mixture as a pasta sauce to go with the brats; amazing!
Used Sauerkraut instead of onion
The onions were a big hit!

I boiled the brats in the beer and added all the seasonings and the onions. I finished the brats on the grill to give them some grill marks and they were amazing! Love the yummy onion relish on top!!!!
I made these for my family and they loved them! They had so much flavor and were not dried out.
I made this for a German-themed party, and it was a hit!

I followed the recipe ingredients and directions but halved the recipe. I also poked holes in the brats prior to simmering to allow in more flavor and prevent splitting. It was a big hit and I will make it again.
Perfection! Everyone loved it. Strongly recommend.
AWESOME. Every

These are awesome brats! The only thing I changed was after I remove the brats from the beer and onions, I drain off the beer, throw in a little butter and a tad of sugar and cook the onions until carmalized. Perfection!!

I made this recipe as is except that I had to use what I had on hand. First I used Swiss cheese stuffed German sausages. Also, I did not use the pepper flakes as spicy hot upsets our stomachs horribly. With that said, I prepared them per the instructions. I cooked the onions until pretty soft and glossy and most of the liquid was gone. I served the sausages on pretzel buns that I spread with a bit of grain mustard from France I happen to find at the kitchen store. It was delicious! Next time I get beef brats or any good German style pork or beef sausage I will make it this way again. Really, it is an easy recipe that is downright good. Also, make sure you get a really good beer. I used a Belgian wheat beer I found at the grocery store and it came out excellent. The recipe is open to experimentation with either the type of sausage or the type of beer. Will make this again definitely to go out of the beaten path of bbq sausages of any kind. BTW, don't get deterred if you don't have a BBQ, use your broiler for the final browning
Don’t make any changes. These are amazing with the original recipe!

Tried it a couple of times. Doesn't improve the flavor of the Brats. Also, the onions have nothing left in them so there's no reason to add them back to the meat. The _only_ good thing to come out of this recipe is the broth, strained, is delicious.

Very tasty brats! I cooked a dozen and used 3 cans of beer, keeping other measurements the same.
This is a particularly handy recipe for a large group because you can keep them warm easily.
Very tasty....made just as recommended!

I used Ionia78 suggestion and they turned out great. Still used the same basic ingredients, just heated in an aluminum throw-away pan, and cooked the brats over indirect heat for about 20 minutes before placing in the 'sauce'. I've made these several times for parties, and continue to add additional brats each time - and I still don't have leftovers, and usually I don't even get one before their gone (made 21 last time). Lots of compliments on the flavor and juiciness.
I added shredded cabbage and cooked in the crockpot for 5-6 hours. Did not make the full recipe. I only had 5 brats and only 1 can of beer. Hubby enjoyed it! Smelled great when we walked inside!
We cook 1oo or more brats this way for our October fest party
Hubby loved it and raved about it, even the leftovers. Will definitely only cook them this way.
Hubby loved it and raved about it, even the leftovers. Will definitely only cook them this way.
Super easy, very tasty, and you get to enjoy a beer as you make it!
These are AMAZING!
Followed the recipe exactly, but used only eight brats. Easy and delicious. Plenty spicy for this light weight. Will definitely make again.
We just didn't care for ours. It doesn't mean it wasn't good for other people. Were just Hot Link people.
Good flavors, quick lunch
I’ll experiment with different types of beer but overall I would not change it.
When I made this I was fixing 8 brats and had only 2 cans of beer, so that's all I used. They turned out great.
Fool proof recipe. I even used it on hotdogs to give them a kick. The onions and sauce left over make a great garnish.
Definitely one to try.!
Loved it. Followed directions as listed and was the tastiest bunch of Brats I ever had. Very easy and delicious. Might try a different beer next time but wouldn't change anything else.

I've made this dish a few times and the alterations I've settled on are #1 flip the order, grill first until you get the preferred level of grill marks, then simmer in the mixture for like a half hour or longer to absorb the flavor. And #2 my family aren't big beer drinkers so we decided to swap it with Angry Orchard Hard Cider and the apple flavor works with the brat perfectly. If you want beer flavor pick a strong dark, but I prefer the apple myself.
Best recipe I've ever used. If you reduce the serving size it still comes out great!

Make these maybe twice a year and always soak them in Miller High Life which my army vet brother swears is the best for brats-it’s very good so I trust him and always use it- as today. Wanted something to change it up a bit, see what I could do with a brat-this looked perfect; looked super good!

As a transplanted Yooper...who's been making Brats like this for most of my life...I'll also put in a plug for Johnsonville...they are the best! Spent lots of time in Germany in the service, and never encountered a Brautwurst there that came close. As for the recipe, I like the touch of adding the garlic powder and crushed red pepper flakes. It added just the right amount of kick and flavor to make it interesting, but not too much mind you. We wouldn't want anyone to mistake our Brats for Italian Sausage would we. I'll be changing my football season traditions and incorporating this recipe into my routine. As for boiling out the flavor...as the guy said earlier, you don't boil them...just give them a nice warm bath in the beer, butter and onions (and now garlic powder, red pepper flakes, salt and pepper). In fact, I usually take mine out of the freezer and let them defrost in this wonderful bath. You want it hot, but not boiling.

Delicious! This is recipe is wonderful. The only modification I made was to use half of the red peppers because I wasn't sure if it would be too spicy with the full amount. It was perfect. I cut the onions in circular slices and then drained and sauteed them in butter while the brats were grilling to serve as a topping. We served the brats with sauerkraut, relish, the grilled onions, horseradish mustard, and pickled pepperoncinis slices. Mmmm! Will definitely make again. Easy to make for a summer dinner party, and tasty/impressive enough that it doesn't seem like a lazy meal (even though they are).

Followed the recipe as instructed. No edits. In reviewing many of the other reviews, I noticed a distinct difference between the par-boil and grill only sides of the camp. I have to say that par-boiling them helped cook the brats through without overdoing it. I would probably over cook them if grilling only. The seasonings add a nice touch to the flavor. I served it with corn on the cob as another reviewer indicated and a salad and it was a very good meal. I found the “beer mixture” leftover not suitable as a side or topping, but have saved it for a cheese soup, which I think will be fantastic. Props to the recipe owner - this is sure a good recipe! Thanks.

I made as written, but cut amounts in half for one 5 pack of brats - turned out so good - my husband said they were better than his. I used an IPA beer and Johnsonville beer brats. Will keep this as a new family recipe. Thank you for sharing this Zach!
I added about 2 tsp of dry rub, such as Plowboy BBQ Rub. I also added all of my dry ingredients to the beer before bringing to a boil. Brats were very good!
I added about 2 tsp of dry rub, such as Plowboy BBQ Rub. I also added all of my dry ingredients to the beer before bringing to a boil. Brats were very good!
Made it by directions, the only alteration was that we added green peppers to it when we added the onion. This is a keeper recipe!!

Awesome brats! Slight modification using 2 packages (total of 14 brats)...
- used 6 bottles of Yuengling Black & Tan beer (adds great flavor) and 1 cup water
- poked slight holes in each brat before boiling (flavor of beer seeps inside brats)
- after finished boiling, throw on grill on low heat to brown the brats
- after removing from grill, put right back into the pot of beer...that way, the skin on brats don't start shriveling and drying up...keeps the brats nice and juicy!
Family and friends love these...always request to keep making them!!
Very tasty! I used a heavy dark beer then made exactly as listed and seared on grill.
Excellent! I have been making these brats since 2011. I wouldn't change a thing. ENJOY!!!!!
The guys at work ask me to do this about three times a year. I use a porter for the beer.
We have served these many times for football parties. They have great flavor and are easy to prepare. Be sure to serve the onions as a topping! Always a hit!
Had beer brats and didn't want to lose any of that flavor boiling them before the grill. I will do this again with regular brats!
Boiled and then cooked these in my new frying pan. YUM! I'm from Wisconsin and these taste like back home. Thanks!
My husband loved this! Easy to make and he says it’s going to be his favorite

I've made this recipe several times and my family all thought they turned out great. I am not a grill master, so these are perfect for average cooks like me. Just make sure you use a tall enough pot so when the beer boils that it doesn't go over the top.
This was really good and simple. I made half the recipe with two bottles of Guinness Stout and it turned out great. Will make this again.
I added additional onions. I also simmered all of the beer out of the onions and used them as a spicy topping on my brats.
This method made a huge difference versus just throwing them on the BBQ from the package. This will definitely be my go-to method for the rest of the summer - thanks!

Cooked half recipe using Fosters ale and a diced whole onion. The brats were frozen. I put them in the pot, added the rest of the ingredients, brought them to a boil and simmered 25 minutes. While my husband browned the brats on the grill, I brought the onions and broth to a boil, lowering the heat to reduce and simmer. We served the brats on toasted potato hot dog buns, mustard, the onion "jam" reduction and pickled banana and jalapeño peppers. BEST BRATS EVER!
Fantastic 4th of July cookout food. The onion topping really spiced them up.
Loved it! I did put the brats on the grill for a few minutes as well to put grill marks on them and char them. Delicious!

Been using this recipe for 2 years now.. It's my go to for parties.
Only thing i do different is i slow cook the brats on indirect heat while the beer and onions cook. 
I cook out half of the beer/liquid or untill it becomes a bit thicker.
Then i toss in the brats for another 15-20 mins or until most of the beer/liquid is gone and becomes more of a "sauce" 
This dish wont last longer than 5 minutes at a bbq. 
I've been using this for 2 years. Tasty and very simple!
Whoa! Really disappointed with this recipe. I like spicy dishes but this is just way too, in-your-face spicy and doesn't work at all! Never again.
Boiled out all the flavor and then grilled it dry. Horrible

This recipe makes great brats! Had a barbecue with the guys and they all loved it so much we ended up running out. However, it doesn't work on Italian sausages which I cooked in the same batch. They turned out cooked but rather dry. Overall, fantastic. I'll be making these again!
This was a simple, yet very satisfying recipe! I prepared it for my family and added a little Spanish paprika to spice it up a little. Needless to say, not a morsel was left!!!
Delicious! So flavorful. Will make this way from now on.
Get good buns and add a little cream cheese to the bun

This is by far my favorite bratwurst and beer recipe! My husband and I tried this two weekends ago, and it was so much more juicy and flavorful than the other recipes that we have tried. Thanks for sharing!!
It was great, nice and spicy. I have made it a number of times and it always works out well.
I've made this a few times, fantastic as is but I added more onions, we love caramelized onions

All I did was add slices of red and green bell peppers to the mix but otherwise cooked exactly to the recipe. Simple and delicious, full of flavor! The little kick of pepper flakes sure adds zest, and if you're not a fan of that sort of spice it's just as flavorful without. I didn't have any the first time I made this and loved it. The next time I added the pepper flakes and got raves! You can't really mess this up! Thanks for sharing!
I'm making this for about the 10th time today. We love these!! Everyone that we serve them to loves them as well.

AWESOME Recipe!!! Made these for a group of hungry men who couldn't say enough of how these tasted. Followed the recipe but expanded for 20 "brats"...After grilling I dipped them back into the "juices" before placing them on a roll.....AWESOME!!!!

My husband loved it! He also loved the Beer/Cheese soup I made using the beer and seasonings I boiled the brats in. I did everything according to the recipe except that I used 1/4 teaspoon pepper flakes (it was plenty hot) and two bottles of dark beer rather than four.

I simply halved the recipe because I was just cooking for 3 people and sliced the onions instead of dicing. Otherwise, I followed to a T. It was incredibly tasty and I'm making it again this weekend. I didn't eat the cooked down onion mixture simply because I'm not a fan of the texture of onions. However, my husband ate them and said they had a kick. (We're from Texas and not wimpy when it comes to spiciness)
These were juicy and full of flavor.
Great way to fix brats, will definitely make it again

The added flavor comes from the beer and onions. Grill the thawed brats hot and fast until the are brown and just start to split. Then put them in beer and onions. Do not use a miller product! They stink when they boil and they don't taste as good. Budweiser or Old Mil work best. This is also easier for serving over periods of time to a crowd. 

On Wisconsin!
I anticipated a flavor enhancement, and was disappointed. I won't make this again.

This recipe was delicious! I made this for my family last night and they were a huge hit. I followed directions exactly with the exception of not having any garlic powder on hand. I used a tsp of minced fresh garlic instead.

I have to replace my gas grill so I needed a recipe for preparing brats indoors on my electric griddle/grill. Thanks to this recipe and some very helpful reviews, my dinner was a success! I boiled the brats in the given sauce recipe but reduced the heat and let them slow boil for 10 additional minutes while piercing them with a fork to allow the brats to soak up the sauce. I then grilled them on the grill plate of my electric griddle/grill for 15 minutes turning several times to brown them evenly. Everyone loved them! Thanks for the great recipe and reviews, I absolutely love Allrecipes.com!
Made this exactly as stated. They were so moist and tender. Adding this to our summer grilling menu.
